lead_paragraph: Curlin, the reigning Horse of the Year, will stand at stud next year at Lane’s End, a Kentucky horse farm owned by Will Farish, a former United States ambassador to Britain. Farish announced Friday that Curlin, the richest racehorse in North America, would become a stallion at Lane’s End, the Versailles farm where Curlin’s sire, Smart Strike, is already a breeding star. Curlin will command a stud fee of $75,000. ¶Deweycheatumnhowe, the Hambletonian winner and a leading contender for Harness Horse of the Year honors, has developed a throat abscess, jeopardizing his appearance next weekend in the Breeders Crown. He is heavily favored in the 3-year-old Colt Trot, one of eight finals worth a combined $4.9 million at the Meadowlands Racetrack on Nov. 29. dewey.
